stem: A 15-year-old G1P0 client at 30 weeks gestation presents with a weight gain of 6 lbs in 4 days and a headache. Based on the documentation in the Adolescent OB Triage & Risk Profile tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Assessment for hypertension in a very young primipara.
Background: First pregnancy. Age 15. No prior history of hypertension.
Assessment: Client reports, 'My eyes feel blurry and my head hurts really bad.'
Recommendation: Urine protein dipstick and magnesium consult.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 158/104, HR 92, RR 20, T 98.4Â°F. Face and hands are visibly edematous.

actionOptions.text: Place the client in a quiet, dark room to reduce stimulus
Assure the side rails are padded for seizure precautions
Encourage the client to drink caffeinated beverages to help the headache
Position the client flat on her back (Supine) for a fetal exam

parameterOptions.text: Presence of headaches, visual changes, or epigastric pain
Deep tendon reflexes and ankle clonus monitoring
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is Severe Preeclampsia (c2). Risk factors include being a teenager (Age <16) and a first-time mother (Primipara). The BP is in the severe range (158/104) and is accompanied by systemic symptoms (Headache, vision changes, 2+ protein). Priority actions: CNS protection by reducing environmental stimuli (a1) and preparing for potential seizures (a2). Key parameters: Subjective warning signs of eclampsia (p1) and objective CNS irritability (Reflexes/Clonus) (p2).
clinicalPearls: Teens are at much higher risk for preeclampsia due to poor prenatal care and immature vascular systems.
Headache in preeclampsia is usually frontal and does NOT respond to acetaminophen; this indicates cerebral edema.
Never place a pregnant client flat on her back; use a wedge or a side-lying position to avoid Vena Cava Syndrome.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking 3+ reflexes is 'normal' for an agitated teenager.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the BP is high, hyperreflexia is NEVER normal. It is a sign of brain irritation and needs to be addressed immediately with magnesium.

mnemonic.title: Severe P's
mnemonic.expansion: P-Pressure (>160 is emergency). P-Proteinuria. P-Pain (Head/Epigastric). P-Puffy (Face/Hands).
